I see 3 reasons for low yield:

1°) Ni(2+) complexates with organic primary amines... so getting rid of Nickel also get some diamine away... that is probably one of the reason for the use of ion-exchange Dowex. Your Ni(OH)2 had a very turquoise blue haze while it should be greener (maybe is it due to the recording camera balance)... so this may indicate some alkyl-amino complexation sticking to it.

2°) The reaction probably proceed via HOBr just like it does with bleach (NaOCl) and acetic acid to make R-CH(-NCl2)-CO2H from R-CHNH2-CO2H... It makes a N,N-dihaloaminoacid compound that decarboxylates readily to R-NX2 and in basic media generates a nitrile by elimination of two HX.
In the case of an aminated aminoacid... both amino groups may react to form the di-nitrile.

3°) The use of aceton to isolate the final compound is not suitable because of Schiff's base formations...
R-NH2 + O=C(CH3)2 <--==> R-N=C(CH3)2 + H2O

I hope this helps a bit.

To maximize my yield, I would remove the water using a lyophilization process by putting your liquid in a tube with a filter paper on top within the lyophilization flask. If the lyophilization is done at a low temperature, the cadavarine should remain a solid and remain in the container. Then you can add ethanol to liquify the cadavarine in the filter and allow that ethanol to evaporate.

I worked for 8 months with one of my university teacher to analyze an effector of an enzymatic reaction and putrescine was one of the substrate that was used in a reaction to measure the rate of the enzymatic reaction. That reactive smelled awful and oxygen was needed for the reaction so I couldn't close the tube while the reaction was happening.

At some point I used benzaldehyde as a control. God I was happy to work with a substrate what smelled good!

One additional thing other people might not have said is that your NBS was really orange which is normal but actually NBS is supposed to be a colorless solid. It's easy to make it a colorless solid by recrystalizing from water.

I know your extraction step is also probably to blame but just thought I'd mention that that highly orange colored NBS indicated an old sample or slight decomposition. Even with recrystalizing it will definitely revert back to being orange over time just fyi.

Fun fact btw: there are actually some reactions where the impure slightly decomposed orange NBS is PREFERRED over a recrystalizing product. Namely the wohl-ziegler reaction. For other rxns, the pure stuff is preferred.

Well, beside that whole synthesis scheme is pretty gay, cause using green solvents doesnt always make reaction "greener" and using catalyst/NaBH4 mol-ratio 1:1 is really fucked-up (it`s even hard to call NiCl2 a catalyst in this reaction), the point of the second step is just a hetero-phase reduction with in-situ generated H2 and Ni2B as a catalyst (dont remember details, read marchs` Ochem/ phys.chem rewievs if u want them). As obvious u need H2 and some time for driving it to completion cause it is heterogenic. In ur example u  1)just wasted a lot of NaBH4 on generating catalyst 2)Hydrolysis of NaBH4 in H2O is almost instant, so most of H2 does not absorb and just flies away. This method could work only if u d used  x30 NaBH4 excess over catalyst.  Really dude, u picked THE WORSTnd u to always ethod for synthesis - its low yielding, not economical and dangerous. Recommed u to always be suspicious about those 'ONE-POT SUPA-GREEN&FAST' papers

I have been watching your videos and think they are great although some could be used for less than noble purposes.  Some tips/ideas for your cadaverine synthesis and lab tricks in general 1) get some Celite for any filtrations with suspensions, emulsions or flocculent solids, after filtering the solid Ni boride, precipate any remaining nickel as the insoluble oxalate leaving your diamine in solution as it's oxalate salt, filter and strip off water. 3)  an alternative method for converting water soluble amines to their free base from their acid salts is to mix the solid salt with solid NaOH which will liberate the water soluble amine, usually as an oil which can then be extracted more easily. 4) when extracting with lighter than water solvents, decant the upper phase directly from the sep funnel (that is why they have the pear shape).  To separate the last organic extract, drain the aq. phase and dry the inside of the tip after the stopcock w/ a Q-tip, then drain and dry etc. 5)  instead of NaOH, use NH4OH.  The Ni will form a soluble complex which could be treated various ways.  6) If the diamine forms an azeotrope, steam distillation could be another alternative.

Around the turn of the century, they would have added a salt of a heavy metal (lead, mercury, or silver) to the hot solution, which would form a precipitate upon cooling. The precipitate would be filtered and rinsed. It could be added to a small quantity of water, treated with H2S in order to precipitate the metal, while the purified amine salt would remain in solution, which could be concentrated and chilled in order to form crystals. (See pp. 338-339 of https://books.google.com/books?id=HXJKAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA339#v=onepage&q&f=false )

I thought about why your yield might be much lower than the papers. It could be due to the way you added the ingredients. I think that any time that ingredients are added like I feel like adding them the yield is lower unless it's a simple reaction. With more delicate and sensitive molecule reactions the addition of ingredients and conditions have to be just right to get optimal yield. I also think that your idea to evaporate all of the water is a great idea but I think that since the chemical soup being evaporated might become to potent and chemical reactions might occur if to much water is removed possibly destroying the cadaverine but there is only one way to find out. On the other hand the water could be evaporated by 50-85% and I'm sure that would increase the yield while staying on the safe side.

Yo Nile. You could try to use pool ion exchange resins. They're like $6/kg, so it's cheap and usually they're good enough for these kind of things. Just look for the right kind. Usually they are in Na form, but they are highly acidic in nature, so they can be easily activated. They have a different mesh size, but you just have to compensate for that.

I would say to best purification method would be:
after basification filter off all of the solids
set up a simple distillation and distill all the liquids off
Now you should be left with a mixture of cadaverine and water,
acidify with a molar equivalent (to the theoretical yield of cadaverine) of Hcl
evap the water leaving pure cadaverine hcl

possibly you could just distill of the water then switch flasks to collect freebase cadaverine, but I'm guessing the cadaverine would "steam distill" and come over water the water through the entirety of the distillation, but that just my guess.

Converting to freebase:
this is just an assumption, but I beleive freebase cadaverine would highly insoluble in ice cold water so to convert to the freebase
dissolve the cadaverine in a minimum amount of water
dropwise add 6M NaOH until the solution turns basic pH>12, (prob like 2 drops)
place solution in ice bath - solid cadaverine should precipitate below it's mp
vaccuum filter solution and quickly rinse with ice cold acetone
quickly place filter paper in freezer before it melts
once it is at freezer temp scrape crystals into vial.
You may get a better yield by collecting some roadkill. :)

I extracted some aminos In a THF water extraction. if the water has salts the THF will phase out. I've done with some stubborn products adding brine will do the trick if it doesn't phase out at first. also your product might be complexing with the nickel as a bidente chelator. increasing the pH might be helping  it to detach from the nickel but it might not. try using NH4OH as a base. it will complex stronger with the nickel and you won't need to have to filter out the NiOH because Ni ammonium complex is soluble at those pHs. it's worth a try.

One thing I noticed is that your N-bromosuccinimide was very orange. NBS readily releases Bromine upon exposure to light so it must be kept in the dark. For reactions that uses the electrophilic properties of NBS, it is usually recommended to perform them in glassware wrapped in aluminium foil. To obtain pure NBS, you can recrystallise it very easily from 90°C water using 100ml of water for 10g of NBS.

I've had similar problems with partition coefficients going the wrong way with a couple of reactions in my scheme. I would recommend using a more polar solvent like ethyl acetate instead of ether and doing something like ten extractions. You could then reextract it from the organic layer with an aqueous acid solution, wash with ether to remove organic impurities, make it alkaline and salt out the product with brine.

Two suggestions:

1) Basify with NaOH, saturate with NaCl, and extract many times with ether (may need a considerable amount of ether).

2) Basify with NaOH, evaporate to dryness, and extract the solids with ether (may be messy and smelly).

In both cases, skip the final wash with sat. NaCl (since the product is water soluble some of it will be washed away) and instead dry straight away with a basic drying agent like K2CO3 (MgSO4 is somewhat acidic and may complex with amines).

This is a cool video and all, but something in me feels like this was a waste of chemicals. (Kids in Africa could have eaten that sodium borohydride!) By that, I mean that three are cheaper reagents you could have used to perform the same reaction. TCCA in sodium hydroxide is a known reagent to convert amino acids and amines to nitriles ( this would instead give you the dinitrile), and CTH with a tiny amount of palladium catalyst would reduce this to the diamine easily. This follows the same synthetic pathway, but is much more reagent efficient.

Of course, this also neglects direct decarboxylation: although straight heating is a poor method, decarboxylation of amino acids in acetophenone is known to proceed in high yield and at temperatures under 150 C, due to the formation of an imine intermediate which is easier to decarboxylate.

Most likely you are right, the extraction was inefficient:

solubility stated in the rubber: soluble in water; slightly soluble in diethyl ether...
So the 3x30ml of ether for the 150ml solution is not enough the get all the product in the organic phase,
because of the better solubility in water compared to ether.
